venue.name: A.M.C. Highland Center at Crawford Notch

item.description:
NEW HAMPSHIRE SERIES:
Tom, Field, Willey ... Three 4,000-Footers!

EVENT ORGANIZER: Julie Moran. Please contact me here with your thoughts and ideas about this trip: jmmoran {{AT}} nycap.rr.com, Mobile 281-5882. FINISH YOUR NH 48 4,000 LIST WITH US!


ESSENTIAL TRIP DETAILS

Difficulty: 8.5 miles, 3,366' ASL climb, descending the Ethan Pond Trail (AT); 7.5 miles, 3,366' ASL climb, descending via the Kedron Flume. At a 1.5 mile / hour pace this is about a five- or six-hour hike.

CLICK HERE: Google Maps Trailhead Directions, Distances (link) from the Hancock and Big Rock campgrounds (where we will be camping the night before) to the CAR SPOT (the end of Wiley House Road, off of U.S. 302; ALL HIKERS DRIVE HERE FIRST); then to the AMC Highland Center at Crawford Notch, on Route 302, 8.5 miles south from the junction of Route 3, Bretton Woods, NH.

Car Spot Time (the end of Wiley House Road, off of U.S. 302): 8:50 a.m.

Trailhead Time: 9 a.m.


A view of Mt. Washington from the Mt. Tom summit.



TRIP SUMMARY / UPDATES (06/01/2010 11:15 a.m.): This trip is a cross-posted event with a trip scheduled with Hiking Mates CHALLENGE (HMC) and the 4 Seasons Hiking Meetup groups, rescheduled due to bad weather.

This plan follows the Avalon Trail and A-Z Trail routes to Mt. Tom, then across the Willey Ridge Trail to Mt. Field and Mt. Willey. Return to Crawford Notch will be either by the short and steep Kedron Flume Trail, or the Ethan Pond Trail, the AT route back down to a car spot along U.S. 302. We can also opt to simply turn around once we summit Mt. Willey, based on group consensus.

TRAILS OVERVIEW: The Avalon Trail and the steep A-Z Trail leads from the AMC Crawford Notch Visitor Center (railroad depot) to the Willey Range Trail near the summit of Mount Field, passing the excellent viewpoint known as Mount Avalon about 2/3 of the way up. From Mt. Tom heading S-SW, the Willey Range Trail leads from near the height of land on the A-Z Trail over the summits of Mounts Field and Willey, ending at the Ethan Pond Trail. The section below Mount Willey is one of the steepest in the White Mountains, with about 1,600 feet of elevation change in a mile. The Ethan Pond Trail leads from US Route 302 S of Crawford Notch to the Zealand Trail near the AMC Zealand Falls Hut. The entire trail is part of the Appalachian Trail. The Kedron Flume Trail provides an alternate access to the Ethan Pond Trail (Appalachian Trail) starting from the Willey House state park site on US Route 302 just south of Crawford Notch; it is narrower and twistier than the Ethan Pond Trail with a brook crossing that may be difficult in high water.


A classic White Mountains high peak trail, the Willey Ridge Trail Mt. Tom, Mt. Field and Mt. Willey.



ESSENTIALS TO BRING: Flash light AND head lamp, food / snacks / at least three bottles of water, first aid items, sunscreen, bug repellent. Wear multiple layers of synthetic materials for warmth; trekking poles will be helpful gear for this hike.


RESEARCH ESSENTIALS:

CLICK HERE FOR A TRIP PLANNER OF THE HIKE ROUTE -- PRINT AND TAKE A COPY WITH YOU.

Arctic Jay eats from Eric B's hand from the viewpoint just below the summit of Mt. Willey. The slides and the summit of Mt. Webster are in the background.



NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.

WEATHER AND OTHER SUDDEN EVENTS CAN CAUSE SUDDEN CHANGES TO OR CANCELLATION OF THIS EVENT. YOU MUST CHECK BACK TO THE MEETUP.COM SITE OFTEN.

See you there! Julie.
